Def.Name: River Birch
Def.Description: Medium tree growing 40' - 70' feet tall and 15" - 30" in diameter.
Def.Leaves: Alternate, simple, 1" - 3" long, and oval-shaped with serrated edges; they are green above and hairy whitish underneath turning yellow in autumn.
Def.Twigs: Red-brown with white lenticels (dots), shiny, slender male catkins may be present in winter. Buds are bright red-brown and hairy.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Fruit: Nutlet, winged, clustered in a erect, 1" - 1 1/2" long catkin; mature in early summer.
Def.Bark: Light red-brown to salmon pink with shaggy, papery curls.
Def.Range: Hardy to Zone 3b. River birch is native to the eastern United States; south to Florida, north to Minnesota and west to Kansas; it is restricted to stream banks and other moist places.
Def.Remarks: Its young twigs, buds and foliage are browsed by white-tailed deer; seeds are eaten by grouse, turkeys, small birds and rodents. Its spring ripening make it particularly valuable. River birch is useful in native-oriented landscapes. It has a balanced and well-formed growth habit and interesting features through all seasons. Root crowns and roots survive fire and sprout vigorously. The growth rate of river birch is typically 1.5 to 3 feet per year.
